content.title: Choosing the Right Source of Credit
content.subtitle: Comparing credit options for informed borrowing decisions in {{STATE_NAME}}

content.label: Essential Question
content.question:
How do you decide where to borrow money when credit options range from 4% APR to 400% APR?

Not all credit is created equal. The source you choose can mean the difference between an affordable loan and a debt trap.

objectives.description: Understand the key differences between credit sources such as banks, credit unions, online lenders, and payday lenders
Evaluate the terms, interest rates, and fees associated with different credit options to identify total borrowing costs
Assess your own creditworthiness and determine which credit source is most suitable for your specific needs
Examine real-world scenarios to understand how borrowing decisions impact long-term financial health

terms.definition: The yearly cost of borrowing money, expressed as a percentage, including interest and fees
terms.example: A credit card with 18% APR means you'd pay $180 annually on a $1,000 balance

terms.definition: An asset that a borrower pledges as security for a loan, which the lender can seize if payments aren't made
terms.example: Your home serves as collateral for a mortgage; your car for an auto loan

terms.definition: A loan repaid in fixed monthly amounts over a set period of time
terms.example: A 48-month car loan with $350 monthly payments is installment credit

terms.definition: A measure of how likely a borrower is to repay debt, based on credit history and financial factors
terms.example: A credit score of 750 indicates high creditworthiness to lenders

leftPanel.title: Where Can You Borrow?
paragraphs: Different lenders serve different needs and charge very different rates. Understanding your options helps you make smart borrowing decisions in {{STATE_NAME}}.
bulletPoints: Commercial banks offer diverse products but require good credit
Credit unions are member-owned with typically lower rates
Online lenders provide convenience with quick approvals
Consumer finance companies serve those with limited credit

leftColumn.title: Traditional Lenders
items: Build credit history when payments reported
Banks, credit unions, established finance companies

leftPanel.title: Key Differences That Affect Your Rate
paragraphs: Banks are for-profit and shareholder-owned. Credit unions are non-profit, member-owned cooperatives ‚Äî which means their profits go back to members as lower rates.
bulletPoints: Credit unions often offer 0.5-2% lower rates than banks
Banks may have more branch locations and services
Credit unions require membership eligibility
Both are federally insured (FDIC / NCUA)

stats.label: Average rate savings at credit unions

layoutData.title: What to Evaluate Before Borrowing
bulletPoints: APR: The true annual cost including interest and fees ‚Äî the most important comparison factor
Loan Terms: Length of repayment period affects monthly payment and total interest paid
Fees: Application, origination, late payment, and prepayment penalty fees
Credit Requirements: Minimum credit score and income documentation needed
Collateral: Whether the loan requires security like a home or vehicle
Flexibility: Options for payment timing, amounts, and hardship programs

leftColumn.title: Lower-Cost Sources (6-36% APR)
items: Build credit history with each on-time payment

rightColumn.title: High-Cost Sources (100-400%+ APR)
items: Only consider as absolute last resort
80% of payday loans are rolled over

leftPanel.title: The True Cost of Borrowing
paragraphs: The same $1,500 loan from different sources has dramatically different total costs.
bulletPoints: Credit union at 8% APR: total cost $1,562 over 12 months
Bank credit card at 18% APR: total cost $1,648 over 12 months
Payday lender: could cost $3,000+ due to fees and rollovers
12 million Americans use payday loans annually

stats.label: Extra cost from wrong credit choice
Average annual payday fees per borrower

leftPanel.title: New Options to Know
paragraphs: Financial technology has created new types of credit sources with different advantages and risks.
bulletPoints: Fintech Lenders ‚Äî Online-only lenders use AI for faster approvals and may offer competitive rates
Peer-to-Peer ‚Äî Platforms connect borrowers directly with individual investors
Buy Now Pay Later ‚Äî Short-term installment plans at checkout, often 0% if paid on time
Credit Building ‚Äî New tools help build credit history through rent, utilities, and subscriptions

stats.label: Fintech approvals in minutes vs. days
BNPL if paid on time (watch the fine print)
Credit-building tools for thin credit files

scenario.name: Maya's Emergency Car Repair
paragraphs: Maya needs $1,500 for car repairs to get back to work. She has three options: credit union personal loan at 8% APR (12 months = $1,562 total), credit card at 18% APR ($1,648 total if paid in 12 months), or a payday loan at 400% APR equivalent ($2,250+ total).
The credit union loan saves Maya $688 compared to the payday option ‚Äî worth the 2-3 day wait for approval.

scenario.name: Jordan's Used Car Purchase
paragraphs: Jordan is buying a $12,000 used car with a credit score of 720. She compared: bank auto loan at 4.5% APR for 48 months ($13,128 total), dealer financing at 6.9% APR for 60 months ($14,364 total), and online lender at 5.2% APR for 48 months ($13,320 total).
The bank auto loan saves Jordan $1,236 over dealer financing. Longer loan terms lower payments but cost more in total interest.

content.question:
Why do payday lenders continue to operate despite charging extremely high interest rates?

What circumstances might lead someone to use a payday lender even knowing the high costs? What alternatives could help people in financial emergencies avoid high-cost borrowing?

What would you do if you needed $2,000 quickly for an unexpected expense?

What credit sources would be available to you based on your current financial situation? How would you compare the total cost of different options before making a decision?

questions.question: What does APR include that a simple interest rate might not, and why is this important for comparing credit options?
Why might a credit union offer better rates than a commercial bank for the same type of loan?
If a payday loan charges $15 per $100 borrowed for two weeks, what is the approximate APR equivalent?
Besides interest rate, what other factors should you consider when choosing between credit sources?

takeaways.title: Compare APR
takeaways.description: Always look at the Annual Percentage Rate to understand the true cost of borrowing, including all fees

takeaways.title: Shop Around
takeaways.description: Get quotes from at least three different lenders before committing to any credit product

takeaways.title: Avoid Predatory Lenders
takeaways.description: Payday loans and title loans should only be a last resort due to extremely high costs

takeaways.title: Calculate Total Cost
takeaways.description: Look beyond monthly payments to understand the total amount you'll repay over the loan term

main.title: Comparing Credit Sources
main.description: Analyze different borrowing scenarios and determine the most appropriate credit source based on APR, terms, and total cost. You will compare at least three credit options for each scenario.

steps: Review the chart of different credit sources and their characteristics
Analyze each borrowing scenario for amount needed and credit situation
Match each scenario to the most appropriate credit source
Calculate the total cost for at least one scenario option
Reflect on why payday lenders persist despite high costs
